reviewText: This show was originally released on A&E with interludes before mid-ad's and ending credits. It gave the show a hip feel that other detective shows didn't have. I was disapointed that the compleated series did not include these interludes. The interludes contained animation of the Title and a contorted shadow figure of the title caracter himself.Why Timeless video edited this out is beyound me! When you advertise "COMPLETE" it's suppose to be everything in the show.I was around when that show aired, so I remember those things! Otherwise a nice addition to anybody's collection.
summary: Completed Series lacks the most hippest part.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you grew up during the early to mid 1960's everyone saw Peter Gunn. The classy P.I. who also worked well with police Lt. Jacobi on some cases. I have not had time to watch all these yet but I can say the picture quality is the best I have seen to date compared to earlier releases on other disc sets and tapes and the sound quality is better too. Also to own every episode made in this set is a definite plus. I always double-check episode title listings and seasons against the ep guides episode listing sheets-they are definitely all here. Being a half hour detective show means these stories move quickly and have plenty of action, style, and romance throughout the series. Be aware this show was on tv in 1958 through 1961 the era where the crime shows and westerns ruled the networks. The difference in this show is that Blake Edwards created the style of Peter Gunn very well played by Craig Stevens, the stories are fast-paced, and the music is the best plus done by Henry Mancini. If you grew up in that time zone and only saw a few shows, you need to buy this set. As a whole you will not be dissapointed in this episode set.  My only one dissapointment  is that  there was one Peter Gunn Movie made and it was in color simply called "GUNN...NUMBER ONE" done in the late 1960's starring Craig Stevens who did this after the series ended for the movie theaters and it also starred Ed Asner, Albert Paulsen' and Sherry Jackson and this movie is not included in this set.I only hope that it becomes available in the near future. That movie score was also done by Henry Mancini. Another one shot picture of Peter Gunn was made for tv several years later that starred Peter Strauss as Gunn but that was it. Still I rate this set a 5 for it's quality, pricing, completeness of episodes and many exciting shows with a great cast.

reviewText: The complete Peter Gunn DVD set is a" must have" if you ever enjoyed this show from the past.  The quality of the reproduction (both audio and video) is very well done.  The music score by Henry Mancini puts the show over the top.  This is the "coolest" show that has ever been on TV and to be able to now own the complete series is a real find,  The prior set of DVDs put out by A&E were not bad but this collection takes the cake.  If this is your type of show, don't hesitate - Buy it.  You will be very pleased.
Title: N/A

reviewText: PETER GUNN - FILM NOIR COMES TO TV BIG TIMELA MovieGuy,I have viewed the PETER GUNN set and I can tell youI have never seen the series captured on DVD withsuch vivid shades of light and dark, especially theblacks against black areas. The black wet streetsemptied of parked cars, the neon blinking wash oflight and dark, all captured beautifully.The audio is good enough toreally showcase how Blake Edwards and Henry Manciniused variance in sound for dramatic effect.I don't believe I realized how effectively they did it,nor how concentrated an effort it was to pull it off.TV sets in the late 50s weren't noted for sophisticatedsound.You can read my review of the set on COMICS BULLETIN.
summary: PETER GUNN:  FILM NOIR COMES TO TV BIG TIME

reviewText: My copy of PETER GUNN: THE COMPLETE SERIES (created & produced by the great Blake Edwards!) arrived the other week from Amazon and I've been watching it practically non-stop :)!  The PICTURE & SOUND quality is (for the most part) FANTASTIC!  Timeless Media did a bang-up job on this DVD release!  Each season is safely contained in its own plastic DVD case, with 4 discs per case, 2 discs on each facing side (with slight overlap of the discs).  All three seasons fit snugly in the outer box.  The episode titles are printed on each disc and the series is presented in broadcast order.  PETER GUNN is a top-notch DVD release--order it today--you won't be sorry!!!*****Hopefully--one of these days--whichever studio (Fox?  Paramount?) owns the rights to David Janssen's RICHARD DIAMOND, PRIVATE DETECTIVE [a.k.a. CALL MR 'D'] (1957-60--77 half-hour episodes) will release a Complete Series DVD set...!!!  That would be a dream come true!
summary: FANTASTIC PICTURE & SOUND!  Bring it on--Peter Gunn has arrived!

reviewText: I've waited for years for the "Peter Gunn" collection to be available in DVD form.  It was well worth the wait.  This set includes all 114 episodes plus an audio CD featuring the Peter Gunn Theme.Produced by Blake Edwards (The Pink Panther, SOB) for the late 50's TV market.  It stars Craig Stevens as Gunn, beautiful Lola Albright as his girlfriend Edie and not only is she his girlfriend but the featured singer at Mother's nightclub and later at Edie's (her own nightclub).  His police buddy Lt. Jacoby is played well by Herschel Bernardi.  Gunn and Jacoby have a wonderful relationship in the show.  Gunn parades around in stylish Plymouth convertibles in which the top seems to be down regardless of the weather.The set comes in a nicely constructed box with three DVD cases inside.  Each case features one of the three seasons and each contains four DVDs.  The picture and sound have been restored nicely.  The only disappointment with the whole set is the sound seems to increase and decrease frequently.If you like early 50's TV, then "Peter Gunn - The Complete Series" is for you.
summary: As good today as they ever were!

reviewText: This show was hot when I kid. It had action, good music and most of all CLASS! When it comes to tv detectives Peter Gunn has to be in the top five of all times. Along with great action it had the best theme music on tv. It's more than 50 years since I saw this show. It's just as I remembered it. We all wanted to be Peter Gunn. To sum it up Peter Gunn is the detective version of James Bond (Sean Connery).
summary: Craig Stevens was the coolest Cat on tv!

reviewText: I love this series, and for the content and the video quality I would have gladly given 5 stars.  The picture is great, especially compared to some other series from the same era.  But in the menus the sound is deafening, you have to turn it down for your ears' sake, I almost want to say, to keep your sanity.  As soon as the story starts, you have to turn up the sound again, almost full blast to be able to hear what is going on.  This means that you cannot let go of the remote control, especially since the show has one disadvantage, there is no "Play All" setting.  Each episode has to be chosen separately, and if you forget that the sound is turned up high, your ears will suffer.For that I had to deduct 2 stars.
summary: Video quality great - sound very bad

reviewText: Millions of people are familiar with the classic  Jazz theme song for Peter Gunn, but not many have ever watched the original 1950's TV shows. All of a sudden, thanks to Timeless Media Group's release of this 12 DVD set, you can own and watch the complete series for a very reasonable low price. The video and audio quality is very good to excellent-it is not an issue. Just buy it, play it, and enjoy classic 1950's American cops and robbers TV at its best. Craig Stevens is fantastic as Peter Gunn, and composer Henry Mancini provides a soundtrack that compliments the action to perfection.
summary: The Original Hipster TV Detective Show

reviewText: I don't know how this series lasted so long unless it was just about the only thing on TV at the time. Craig Stevens is an OK actor in the style of his period, but the number two billing goes to Lola Albright and for my money far too much time is spent listening to her uninvolved singing using her limited lounge singer talent. A mediocre actress with even more limited acting skills. Not worth the money!

reviewText: If you're old enough to remember ' Peter Gunn ' when it was on TV in the late 1950s, and you liked it, then this DVD collection will please you. A little tweaking of the screen brightness and contrast may be needed but otherwise the picture quality is quite good (and the sound is fine).I have been surprised at how some TV shows from that era have not survived the passage of time gracefully (i.e. their picture quality is not good) but ' Peter Gunn ' was recorded on some medium that has held up well.For people not familiar with that TV era you will want to be aware that the frequent use of guns is pretty much the norm when dealing with ' the bad guy '. Peter Gunn, and his friend Sgt Jacobi, pull their pistols fairly often so if a quick (and noisy)  solution is not your cup-of-tea then be forewarned.One thing that I did not remember (I was fairly young when ' Peter Gunn ' was on-the-air) is how much 1950s jazz is featured (at least so far in the first few shows that I have watched). The series gives a real ' film noir ' sense ... Peter Gunn is ALWAYS immaculately dressed in a suit-and-tie regardless of whether he is listening to his girlfriend singing at ' Mother's ' or having it out with ' the bad guy ' (read  noisy).I was rather nervous when ordering ' Peter Gunn ', not sure of what I was going to receive, but that is behind me now .... it's very enjoyable.
summary: The ' Peter Gunn ' DVD collection (' The Complete Series ' ) Is Very Good

reviewText: When Peter Gunn came on scene back in the late 1950s there had never been anything on TV like it before, and nothing since. Blake Edwards' creation was the coolest private eye anyone had ever seen on the home screen. Casting was inspired with Craig Stevens as Gunn, looking hip in expensive wardrobe, stylishly coordinated. His haircut - based on Cary Grant's hair style - was much admired and emulated. Stevens once said, "Basically it was a crew cut that was parted. Lola Albright was Edie Hart, his sexy, sultry girlfriend singing old standards backed up by an ultra hip combo at Mother's on the waterfront of an unnamed city. Herschel Bernardi's portrayal of police Lieutenant Jacoby was also something new on the tube. Jacoby and Gunn had a love-hate relationship that crackled on screen. Of course, the glue that kept it all together was and still is some of the hippest progressive jazz ever written and recorded by Henry Mancini. It made him in the music business. In season one Hope Emerson played Mother as a bold, brassy and well-connected old broad. Season's two and three she was replaced by another character actress, Minerva Urecal. Adding to mix were the myriad Gunn informants - a host of fabulously off-center out of main stream types portrayed by great supporting actors of that era. Edwards ran a tight ship as creator producer-writer-director with his hardworking staff writers and directors to turn out the half-hour black and white noir gems. The Timeless Video Group has made the entire series shine in sound and visuals. I do not hesitate to recommend this series to any one who loves polished economic production of action-humor-tight plotting-fine acting and one of the best jazz scores ever produced.
summary: Nothing Like It Before Or Since

reviewText: I enjoyed this series as it told great stories in just a half hour while others since have bored me when all other P. I.  shows went to an hour format. I believe a great story can be told in a half hour which the PETER GUNN series proved 117 times over...
summary: Peter Gunn was a great P. I. show which paved the way for the many that would follow.
